question: In healthy adults, does short-term chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA) treatment reduce whole-body energy expenditure compared with baseline or placebo? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Whole-body energy expenditure was also increased upon CDCA treatment.
content.source_2: In a randomized, placebo-controlled crossover trial of 12 healthy women, two days of chenodeoxycholic acid administration reduced resting energy expenditure relative to placebo as assessed by indirect calorimetry.
content.source_3: In rodents, BAT can be activated by bile acids, which activate type 2 iodothyronine deiodinase (D2) in BAT via the G-coupled protein receptor TGR5, resulting in increased oxygen consumption and energy expenditure.
content.source_4: Under thermoneutral conditions, CDCA exposure suppressed D2 activity in brown adipose tissue and was accompanied by a decrease in whole-body oxygen consumption and total energy expenditure.
